# Admitting That You've Done The Very Best You Can Do
## You’re not in high school any more. It’s time to stop hedging your bets.
By [Mark Herrmann](https://abovethelaw.com/author/mark-herrmann/)  
onJune 13, 2016 at 10:10 AM
0
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/admitting-that-youve-done-the-very-best-you-can-do/&text=Admitting%20That%20You’ve%20Done%20The%20Very%20Best%20You%20Can%20Do)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/admitting-that-youve-done-the-very-best-you-can-do/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/admitting-that-youve-done-the-very-best-you-can-do/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Maybe you have this in common with me: In high school, you didn’t study very much.

On reflection, this was to manufacture an excuse. If you got an “A” on the test without having studied, that was great. If you didn’t get an “A,” you had an excuse: “If I’d bothered to study, I would have gotten an ‘A.'”

That same attitude carries over into the law.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
As an associate who had just moved laterally from a small firm to a big one, I was nervous: “These big firm guys might be really good. Suppose my very best work isn’t up to par?”

I knew I had to knock the ball out of the park to convince the new guys I was trustworthy. So I overworked stuff: To ensure that my work product was up to snuff, I put too much time into each of the first few projects that I was given. I figured that people would come to respect the quality of my work, and no one cared about the amount of time I put into a project. (When the time comes to make partner, people are thinking: “Do I want to have that guy with me or against me?” They are not thinking: “How quickly did he do the project?” Or, as one of my former partners put it, decades later: “No one ever failed to make partner at this firm by being too conscientious.”)

So I put too much time into drafting one brief. I fired off every last neuron ginning up arguments; I polished the prose until it glittered. And then, to hedge my bets, I left the draft on the partner’s chair with a note: “Here’s an early first draft of the brief, just to give you a sense of where we’re going. After I get your comments, I’ll put this into final.”

Perfect! If he doesn’t like the draft, I can just say, “Well, it was an early draft.” Then I can try to figure out what he’s after.

### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
The next day, the partner called me into his office: “Can you tell me exactly what else you were planning to do to this brief? I’m a pretty harsh critic, and I normally mark things up pretty extensively. But I wouldn’t change a word of this. Just what were you planning to do to make it better?”

Sometimes, the world calls your bluff. For that question, I had no answer.

For years, I saw this at law firms: Sometimes people really did give me crappy drafts, with notes that said, “Here’s a crappy draft. I just want to get your thoughts.” I’ll tell you what I thought: “Why would you possibly ever give a partner a crappy draft? I don’t want to do your work for you. Do the very best you can do; then, give it to me. Why would anyone do anything else?”

On the other hand, sometimes people gave me finished, perfect drafts, accompanied by notes, “Here’s a crappy draft. I just want to get your thoughts.” I’d read the note and think: “Shoot. Here we go again.” But then I’d read the brief and understand what was going on: “The associate is just hedging because he doesn’t want to admit this is his best work. But this is pretty damn good.”

I never received a draft brief accompanied by a note that said: “Here’s the very best I can do. Does it make the grade?”

[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
No one wants to know the answer to that question.

What do I see now that I’m in-house?

Law firms send me “early drafts” of briefs for my review: “Here’s an early draft. We just want to get your thoughts.”

What are they — in high school all over again?

I don’t want to review multiple drafts, each one slightly improved from the last version. I want to read one draft, perfect and ready to go, so that I can sign off on it.

Perhaps this is just hedging: “I hear Herrmann‘s a [curmudgeon](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1590316762/ref=as_li_ss_tl?ie=UTF8&tag=dealbreaker-20&linkCode=as2&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=1590316762). Maybe he won’t like what I wrote. I’d better say it’s just an early draft.”

Fortunately, my students are educable these days. I explain that I want to see only their very best work. When it’s ready to go to court, it’s ready for my review; until then, keep polishing.

And get me the draft a couple of days early, too, so I have time to review the thing — because when you think something’s ready for court, you might be wrong.

An outside counsel recently told me that he has his partners “Herrmann-ize” briefs before they come to me. He’s wrong. That concept doesn’t exist: Either a brief is ready for prime time — to be filed in court — or it isn’t ready to be sent to an in-house litigator who has time only to review one draft. It’s final, or it’s not: Making something suitable for me is irrelevant.

You’re not in high school any more. It’s time to stop hedging your bets.

Mark Herrmann is Vice President and Deputy General Counsel – Litigation and Employment at [Aon](http://www.aon.com/), the world’s leading provider of risk management services, insurance and reinsurance brokerage, and human capital and management consulting. He is the author of [The Curmudgeon’s Guide to Practicing Law](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1590316762/ref=as_li_ss_tl?ie=UTF8&tag=dealbreaker-20&linkCode=as2&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=1590316762) and [Inside Straight: Advice About Lawyering, In-House And Out, That Only The Internet Could Provide](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1614385394/ref=as_li_ss_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=1614385394&linkCode=as2&tag=dealbreaker-20) (affiliate links). You can reach him by email at [inhouse@abovethelaw.com](mailto:inhouse@abovethelaw.com).

# New Year, New Look For This Biglaw Firm
## A bold look for the new decade.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJanuary 16, 2020 at 11:15 AMJanuary 16, 2020 at 10:45 AM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/01/new-year-new-look-for-this-biglaw-firm/&text=New%20Year,%20New%20Look%20For%20This%20Biglaw%20Firm)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/01/new-year-new-look-for-this-biglaw-firm/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/01/new-year-new-look-for-this-biglaw-firm/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Who doesn’t love a shiny new makeover? The Biglaw firm formerly known as Wiley Rein has decided to go bold in the new decade, shortening their name (at least in marketing materials) to Wiley and using the .law exchange (a move they believe to be a first for an Am Law 200 firm).

Wiley.law is also shaking up their look. Gone from their homepage is the staid green and white palette in favor of a bold red and purple look:



[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
 

As managing partner Peter Shields [told Law.com](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2020/01/15/wiley-rein-drops-rein-adds-new-look-and-moves-to-law-domain/), the new look was designed to turn heads:

“We decided as a partnership that the timing was right,” managing partner Peter Shields said in an interview. “We have a focus on some new practices and thought it was time for our brand to reflect that.”

….

The colors, according to Shields, were recommended by Dharma Pachner, chief creative officer at consulting firm Contrast and Co. “He said the overall look and vibrancy reflected what he heard from the stakeholders. We never looked back,” said Shields.

And the firm’s powers that be believe the new look matches up well with the legal services they provide their clients:

From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)

Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
“Since our founding, clients have turned to Wiley to solve their most pressing issues and anticipate the challenges that lie ahead,” Shields said in a statement. “Our new brand represents who we are today—a firm with a focused mindset, interdisciplinary depth, a celebration of diversity, and a culture of collegiality.”

Best of luck with the new look.

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, and host of [The Jabot podcast.](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA) AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter (@Kathryn1).

# Sidley Sidles Up To The New Salary Scale
## Congratulations!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 21, 2021 at 12:44 PMJune 21, 2021 at 12:01 PM
27
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/sidley-raise-2021/&text=Sidley%20Sidles%20Up%20To%20The%20New%20Salary%20Scale)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/sidley-raise-2021/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/sidley-raise-2021/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
There’s nothing quite like finding out that you’re getting a raise on a Monday morning. That’s what happened at Sidley Austin today, and associates seem to be quite pleased. Was there ever any doubt that the firm would risk not raising its salaries and drop to a lower pay tier? Of course not.

The firm, which came in at #6 in the last Am Law 100 ranking, taking $2,462,935,000 gross revenue in 2020, made the announcement earlier today that associate salaries would be bumped up to meet the Davis Polk scale.

Here’s what the new salaries looks like at Sidley:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
- 2021: $205,000
- 2020: $205,000
- 2019: $215,000
- 2018: $240,000
- 2017: $275,000
- 2016: $305,000
- 2015: $330,000
- 2014: $350,000
- 2013: $365,000
Congratulations to everyone at at the firm!

(Flip to the next page to see the full memo from Sidley Austin.)

Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

[Pro Bono](https://abovethelaw.com/pro-bono/), [Small Law Firms](https://abovethelaw.com/small-law-firms-topic/), [Solo Practitioners](https://abovethelaw.com/solo-practitioners/)
# 500 Hours Of Pro Bono Work: Bumped Down at Biglaw, Bankrupted At Small Law, And Barely Making A Dent Towards Access To Justice
## Should Biglaw firms stop doing pro bono work? The answer may be "yes."
By [Carolyn Elefant](https://abovethelaw.com/author/carolynelefant/)  
onDecember 6, 2016 at 2:47 PM
24
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/500-hours-of-pro-bono-work-bumped-down-at-biglaw-bankrupted-at-small-law-and-barely-making-a-dent-towards-access-to-justice/&text=500%20Hours%20Of%20Pro%20Bono%20Work:%20Bumped%20Down%20at%20Biglaw,%20Bankrupted%20At%20Small%20Law,%20And%20Barely%20Making%20A%20Dent%20Towards%20Access%20To%20Justice)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/500-hours-of-pro-bono-work-bumped-down-at-biglaw-bankrupted-at-small-law-and-barely-making-a-dent-towards-access-to-justice/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/500-hours-of-pro-bono-work-bumped-down-at-biglaw-bankrupted-at-small-law-and-barely-making-a-dent-towards-access-to-justice/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Last week, [Bloomberg](https://bol.bna.com/lawyer-who-helped-save-death-row-inmate-didnt-make-partner/) reported on [Brian Stolarz](https://www.leclairryan.com/brian-w-stolarz/), a former senior associate with [K&L Gates](http://www.klgates.com/) whose heroic pro-bono efforts helped a former death-row inmate win his freedom — but couldn’t win Stolarz partnership at his firm. Predictably, the firm’s partnership decision came down to hours: K&L Gates had an annual 2000-hour billable requirement, Stolarz admitted that he “was probably billing 1,400, and [around 500 pro bono]. As a result, Stolarz had to settle for an of-counsel position — though he’s since left K&L Gates and is now a partner at [LeClair Ryan](https://www.leclairryan.com).

The Bloomberg piece valiantly tries to make the counter-case that large global law firms should count all pro bono work towards associates’ billable requirements. Yet even if more firms adopted a parity-for-pro-bono-hours policy, it’s unlikely that this change would make a difference since most of the nameless attorneys interviewed for the article said that irrespective of their firm’s official pro bono policies, ultimately, their careers are judged by hours billed.

And that makes sense. After all, where else on the planet can employees who are hired and paid to perform a particular job devote a quarter of their work-time to charity and volunteer endeavors and still expect the same salary and advancement opportunities? That Uber driver who volunteers two mornings a week shuttling old folks to doctors’ appointments doesn’t even get paid for those hours. Ditto the grocery store worker who runs around town collecting canned goods for the local food bank.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Likewise, the universal rule that hours worked = income and benefits received applies in solo and small law land too. Solo lawyers who choose to spend 500 hours a week of their time on pro bono matters would soon find themselves not merely bumped down from the prospect of a high-six figure partnership salary to low six-figure of-counsel position, but flat out bankrupt. And large firms aren’t immune either: granted, a large firm that writes off 500-hours of billable time won’t go out of business, but multiply those 500 hours 500 times over, and you’re looking at a serious revenue loss.

Moreover, if the purpose of pro bono work is to expand access to justice rather than merely serve as a law firm recruitment tool, arguably, it’s efficient for large firms to fund legal aid organizations or pay solos to do pro bono work. Do the math: if Stolarz had spent 500 hours on billable work instead of pro bono, he would have conservatively generated $157,000 in revenues for the firm (assuming $450/hr rate x 500 hrs, applying a 70% realization rate). Stolarz’s foregone revenue funded one capital case, which is undoubtedly important. But those dollars would have gone much farther if donated to a non-profit focused on capital cases. Heck, $157,000 could pay for two solo lawyers to each take on a year’s worth of free and low-bono divorce, domestic violence, immigration and landlord-tenant cases — matters where representation is desperately needed.

Some large firms may be heading in that direction — effectively “outsourcing” their pro bono obligations by supporting other attorneys or organizations to provide legal services. For example, the Bloomberg mentions an initiative by [Jones Day](http://www.jonesday.com/) to set up a network to help military veterans obtain legal services. And for years, Skadden has operated [fellowship program](https://www.skaddenfellowships.org/) that pays the salary for 30 attorneys to work at legal aid organizations.

Decades ago, I published a [law review article](http://www.law.ua.edu/pubs/jlp_files/issues_files/vol16/vol16art06.pdf) questioning whether Biglaw pro bono programs are the most effective way to expand access to justice. Today, I’m more convinced than ever that these programs don’t work since despite the thousands of hours of pro bono time logged by Biglaw firms each year, the majority of low income people are consistently unable to afford legal services. Instead of forcing firms to forego revenue to benefit a handful of associates who take on pro bono work, why not ask them to spread the wealth to support solo and non-profit law firms who can do pro bono and low-bono work more efficiently and affordably?

# Former Biglaw Associate Explains How He's Going To 'Outwit' The Competition On 'Survivor'
## Will this lawyer be able to outlast the other contestants on 'Survivor'?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJanuary 23, 2024 at 4:46 PMJanuary 23, 2024 at 2:57 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/former-biglaw-associate-explains-how-hes-going-to-outwit-the-competition-on-survivor/&text=Former%20Biglaw%20Associate%20Explains%20How%20He’s%20Going%20To%20‘Outwit’%20The%20Competition%20On%20‘Survivor’)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/former-biglaw-associate-explains-how-hes-going-to-outwit-the-competition-on-survivor/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/former-biglaw-associate-explains-how-hes-going-to-outwit-the-competition-on-survivor/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

A lot of people don’t like lawyers until a lawyer saves their ass and then that lawyer is their favourite person in the whole wide world and that person will be me out here.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
— [Charles Noonan](https://au.linkedin.com/in/charlesnoonan), a former litigation associate at Gibson Dunn who now serves as special counsel at Australia’s Maurice Blackburn, explaining why he’ll be a force to be reckoned with during his upcoming [stint as a contestant](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/wake-up-call-hogan-others-bill-kansas-millions-in-ncaa-probe) on [“Australian Survivor: Titans v Rebels.”](https://survivor.fandom.com/wiki/Charles_Noonan) Noonan went on to say, “My day job is to outwit my opponents and that’s exactly what I’m gonna do on Survivor.” The first episode of the show is set to air later this month.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) and [Threads](https://www.threads.net/@stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# Biglaw Layoffs In A Pandemic: Opportunistic Or Necessary?
## We generally expect to see firms with entrenched corporate practices suffer the most.
By [Lateral Link](https://abovethelaw.com/author/lateral-link/)  
onApril 3, 2020 at 2:44 PMApril 13, 2020 at 5:39 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/biglaw-layoffs-in-a-pandemic-opportunistic-or-necessary/&text=Biglaw%20Layoffs%20In%20A%20Pandemic:%20Opportunistic%20Or%20Necessary?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/biglaw-layoffs-in-a-pandemic-opportunistic-or-necessary/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/biglaw-layoffs-in-a-pandemic-opportunistic-or-necessary/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Are law firms laying off associates and staff as a sword or a shield in this COVID-19 pandemic? This question predicates on whether we are headed for another protracted recession a la 2009, or if ultimately this is just a short-term blip. The answer is a moving target; ultimately, we do not know how the virus will play out. Optimistic models hope for a swift return to normalcy, while more pessimistic counterparts forecast many more months of lockdowns. Regardless of the ultimate answer, firms are preparing for the worst case scenario, as they hope to avoid the same pitfalls that toppled Howrey and Dewey & LeBoeuf during the last recession.

Although the financial crisis is more closely associated with 2009 for Biglaw, the crisis actually started in the spring of 2007. It took time for the full brunt of the downturn to propagate to Biglaw. As we can see, the ratio for lateral moves to lateral leakage (attorneys exiting Biglaw altogether) hit its nadir for partners in 2010, declining year for year starting in 2007.


Despite hitting its low point three years after the recession again, the market quickly resurged the following year as lateral movement increased relative to leakage. Associate movement is often a more sensitive barometer for market conditions as associate laterals take less time to execute and swarms of partners are insulated from recessions if they have strong portables or are in key practices. If we look at just associate leakage, and add further granularity to the best fit model, we see that market conditions actually started improving in 2010.


There is one caveat, this “growth” was driven not by an increase in appetite, but rather a decrease in associate layoffs.


Data supports the consensus that 2009 was the year of mass layoffs, as March of 2009 saw over 1,400 attorneys leave Biglaw altogether. Though associate movement increased a paltry 25 percent, compared to the 128 percent from 2010 to 2011, but the mass exodus of attorneys in 2009, seemed to assuage the concerns of most firms on their financial position.


The question on everyone’s minds is, what will firms do this time?

Generally the consensus is split; some firms are opting for austerity measures in the form of pay cuts and frozen partner distributions. These moves suggest that those firms believe this is a short-term crisis, and are deferring risk onto its members in a bid to avoid a repeat of 2009 style layoffs. The less optimistic firms are already resorting to layoffs and furloughs for associates and staff in hard-hit practice areas like M&A.

There will not be a one-size fits all approach, and the firms more diversified, especially in counter-cyclical practice areas like L&E, restructuring, litigation, and tax, are better equipped to weather the storm. Firms like Hueston Hennigan with strong litigation pipelines have actually announced bonuses instead of cuts, on top of their [market-busting bonuses](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/12/hueston-hennigan-bonus-2019/). Hueston Hennigan doesn’t need to address slowing corporate practices with highly paid M&A associates and partners waiting for deal flow.

We generally expect to see firms with entrenched corporate practices suffer the most. White-shoe firms like Simpson Thacher, Cadwalader, Davis Polk, Cravath, Goodwin, Wilkie, Ropes & Gray, Shearman & Sterling, will be hard hit by an extended recession as their large domestic corporate footprint exceeds 40 percent of their domestic practice share.


We expect many of these firms to begin retooling their associates – something Lateral Link’s very own Jon Kahn [experienced](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/01/jon-kahns-journey-from-biglaw-partner-to-recruiting/) when corporate work dried up at Fried Frank when he started in 1990. Firms will continue to bolster practices with stable demand, and we expect to see the lateral market resemble a mosaic as demand increases for certain specialties (especially among partners) and demand otherwise slows for other practices and level of experience niches.

For those that don’t have the capabilities or flexibility to retool their associates, we expect to see layoffs as associates represent a fixed cost for the firms. Because partners are the profit drivers in the Biglaw model, and associates are either profit sources or cost centers depending on their billable revenue generated, firms will protect their partners as much as they can while coveting other firm’s profitable partners. Additionally, layoffs represent a proven financial tool to weather declines in profitability that saw success in the 2009 crisis.


A precipitous drop was avoided in 2009 as firms boosted their PPP by laying off associates in dry practice areas. The reduction in partner profits was offset by the reduction in fixed costs in the form of associate pay. Nonetheless, the move has long-term consequences as it handicaps the profitability and strength of a firm’s practice once it ultimately re-engages its cyclical practices. Though some firms have a head start on layoffs, ultimately we expect firms to opt for a more conservative pruning relative to the deep Edward-Scissorhandesque cuts we saw in 2009 to minimize the opportunity costs associated with hemorrhaging attorneys right before the market reopens.

With such granular demand that differs by specialty and experience, your best bet for making a lateral move right now is to team up with an experienced recruiter who can help you navigate this mercurial market. If you are a partner or firm chair interested in discussing the state of the market, [I am](https://www.laterallink.com/team/michael-allen) happy to discuss what our full-service recruiting firm is seeing in the trenches. If you are a partner, counsel, or associate looking for lateral opportunities, [our recruiters](http://laterallink.com/team) are happy to help you take advantage of unique market conditions to achieve your career and lateral goals.

Ed. note: This is the latest installment in a series of posts from [Lateral Link’s ](http://bit.ly/2b4rW3j)team of expert contributors. [Michael Allen](https://www.linkedin.com/in/michaelallen/) is the CEO of Lateral Link. He is based in the Los Angeles office and focuses exclusively on Partner and General Counsel placements for top firms and companies. Prior to founding Lateral Link in 2006, he worked as an attorney at both Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher LLP and Irell & Manella LLP. Michael graduated summa cum laude from the University of California, San Diego before earning his JD, cum laude, from Harvard Law School.

[Lateral Link](http://laterallink.com/) is one of the top-rated international legal recruiting firms. With over 14 offices world-wide, Lateral Link specializes in placing attorneys at the most prestigious law firms and companies in the world. Managed by former practicing attorneys from top law schools, Lateral Link has a tradition of hiring lawyers to execute the lateral leaps of practicing attorneys. Click [here](https://www.laterallink.com/) to find out more about us.

# Women Underrepresented In Leadership Positions, Overrepresented In Law School Debt
## It doesn’t take a genius to figure that it will still take decades for women lawyers to reach income parity while continuing to pay down law school debt.
By [Jill Switzer](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jillswitzer/)  
onAugust 10, 2023 at 2:44 PMAugust 11, 2023 at 2:27 PM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/women-underrepresented-in-leadership-positions-overrepresented-in-law-school-debt/&text=Women%20Underrepresented%20In%20Leadership%20Positions,%20Overrepresented%20In%20Law%20School%20Debt)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/women-underrepresented-in-leadership-positions-overrepresented-in-law-school-debt/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/women-underrepresented-in-leadership-positions-overrepresented-in-law-school-debt/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Why am I not surprised? Even though women comprise the majority of law school students, they still don’t comprise (not even close) the majority of those in leadership positions in law firms and in corporations. And given the recent Supreme Court decision on affirmative action, that majority may never be reached, especially now that businesses with any kind of DEI policies are [in the litigation crosshairs](https://www.wsj.com/articles/diversity-equity-dei-companies-blum-2040b173).

And what will happen to [all the DEI initiatives](https://www.calbar.ca.gov/Portals/0/documents/reports/Diversity-Equity-Inclusion-Plan-Report-2023-2024.pdf) such as the elimination of bias and the implicit bias training required of all California lawyers? Will such initiatives be canned? To be determined. One lawsuit [against the Medical Board of California](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/litigation/california-doctors-sue-licensing-board-to-undo-dei-requirement?source=newsletter&item=read-text&region=digest) has already been filed.

The corollary to the majority of women in law schools is that women are also carrying [the major portion of the law school debt](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/bloomberg-law-analysis/analysis-the-future-of-legal-is-female-but-it-comes-with-a-cost?source=newsletter&item=body-link&region=text-section).

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
According to Bloomberg, 30% of the respondents to its most recent Law School Preparedness Survey reported having law school debt in the six-figure range, but a gender-based breakdown of the data shows that women make up a majority of those respondents. The same holds true for debt at or above $50,000. Not an easy amount to pay off, especially if women are not pulling down Biglaw salaries, and there’s still significant salary disparity.

All you need to do is to read [this abstract](https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/law-and-social-inquiry/article/abs/gender-pay-gap-and-highachieving-women-in-the-legal-profession/96397A648EBA73213137F40F6CC67B2F) about how women attorneys still continue to lag behind in income. It doesn’t take a genius to figure that it will still take decades for women lawyers to reach income parity while continuing to pay down law school debt. Not a pretty picture.

The conclusion is cringeworthy and discouraging: “discrimination in the legal profession operates partly by devaluing female attorneys’ human capital, such that sterling academic credentials and other traits that are valued in men are far less valued in women.” Is there any woman lawyer who doesn’t know that already?

And how many times have women lawyers been criticized for being aggressive, for being “shrill “(what’s the male counterpart to that adjective?), and/or for speaking up? For being “pushy?” Whatever that means. Too many times to count. Adam Grant, an organizational psychologist at Wharton, thinks it’s [time to normalize language](https://www.nytimes.com/2023/07/31/opinion/women-language-work.html?campaign_id=39&emc=edit_ty_20230802&instance_id=99027&nl=opinion-today&regi_id=78061995&segment_id=140893&te=1&user_id=0d22f8d038b2fef3184a5c3bba481c1c) so that “weak language” (e.g., language such as disclaimers, hedges, and tag questions) can be a strategic advantage and an untapped source of strength.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)

In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law

[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)

### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
We all confront at some point whether we should have a “passion” for what we do. We like to think that we are passionate about what we do, otherwise, why do it, except for the lifestyle that it can afford some, but not all, of us. But what if passion is overrated? Given all that we have endured during the past three years of COVID-19 and now the post-COVID era, many lawyers have come to realize that passion for the work is not necessarily all that we think it is. WFH, hybrid work schedules, and being able to make time for the people and activities that make life worthwhile may well have put the brakes on the constant need to be indispensable, to be available 24/7, to make all the sacrifices that some peeps think are worth making, only to find that they aren’t worth it. That realization comes to everyone, eventually.

What may be an unintended consequence of associate deferral dates at some Biglaw firms may be the chance to think about whether the passion you have is worth the physical, emotional, and mental costs. Stress accompanies every single job, whether a lawyer, first responder, or tradesperson, especially HVAC peeps, the last of which would seem to be in the highest demand right now, given the weather. However, [using passion as the keystone](https://www.ucpress.edu/book/9780520303232/the-trouble-with-passion) to how you regard what you do and who you are can backfire.

What does “judgment” mean? The Orange County legal community here in SoCal is stunned at [the arrest of Orange County Superior Court Judge Jeffrey Ferguson](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/california-judge-arrested-on-suspicion-of-shooting-his-wife-to-death/) who is alleged to have killed his wife in their home in northern Orange County. He’s presently free on a $1 million bond.

In 2017, the California Commission on Judicial Performance [publicly admonished him for two matters](https://cjp.ca.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/40/2016/08/Ferguson-D-O-Public-Admon-5-31-17.pdf), including being Facebook friends with attorneys who appeared before him. He also had made false claims about a prosecutor running for a judicial office. The commission was not happy, especially given the “seriousness of his misconduct in accusing a judicial candidate of ethical impropriety with a reckless disregard for the truth. The judge’s post was not only potentially injurious to the candidate, but also undermined public respect for the judiciary and the integrity of the electoral process.”

Is judgment an oxymoron? In another matter, a judge in the Eastern District of Michigan commented that a defendant appearing in his courtroom “[looked like a criminal”](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/federal-judge-says-defendant-looks-like-a-criminal-to-me-which-is-obviously-a-problem/) to him. He refused to recuse himself, saying that he could be fair, and guess what? The defendant was convicted. No surprise there. The Sixth Circuit benchslapped that district court judge and reversed the conviction. Also, no surprise that the retrial would be before a different judge.

Why can’t judges behave? What exactly is “judicial temperament”? That’s a question that every judicial evaluation questionnaire asks, at least here in California. Shouldn’t such temperament be like counting to 10 and then counting to 10 again? Maybe that 10 should be multiplied.

UPDATE: Prior version incorrectly identified that California Medical Association which is distinct from the California Medical Board.

Jill Switzer has been an active member of the State Bar of California for over 40 years. She remembers practicing law in a kinder, gentler time. She’s had a diverse legal career, including stints as a deputy district attorney, a solo practice, and several senior in-house gigs. She now mediates full-time, which gives her the opportunity to see dinosaurs, millennials, and those in-between interact — it’s not always civil. You can reach her by email at [oldladylawyer@gmail.com](mailto:oldladylawyer@gmail.com?subject=Your%20ATL%20column).

# Elite Litigation Powerhouse Blasts Davis Polk Salary Scale Out Of The Water
## This firm isn't just making it rain on associates -- the firm is making it pour!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJuly 26, 2021 at 12:44 PMJuly 27, 2021 at 12:39 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/williams-connolly-raise-2021/&text=Elite%20Litigation%20Powerhouse%20Blasts%20Davis%20Polk%20Salary%20Scale%20Out%20Of%20The%20Water)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/williams-connolly-raise-2021/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/williams-connolly-raise-2021/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
What’s the best way to ensure that associates at your firm have a wonderful weekend? By announcing big-time — we’re talking huge — salary raises on Friday night. How exciting!

At litigation powerhouse Williams & Connolly, salaries are typically difficult to cover due to the firm’s black-box feel. While salaries are known to be slightly above market, associates at the firm usually remain relatively quiet as far as their compensation is concerned — that is, until now.

Please note the UPDATE below.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
According to memo sent on Friday, the firm is now paying lockstep salaries across all class years, and those salaries are way, way above market. Check it out:



For the Class of 2021, that’s $17,500 more than the DPW scale, and for the Classes of 2013 and earlier, that’s $35,000 more than the DPW scale. That’s quite the payday for associates at the firm.

UPDATE (1:30 p.m.): Sources note that while salaries alone at Williams & Connolly beat the new Davis Polk salary scale, their complete compensation is under market. Why’s that? There are no bonuses of any kind to had at W&C. Without year-end bonuses or special bonuses, the only remarkable thing here is the firm’s above-market raise structure.

###Sponsored

### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)

# Picking Your System -- Part 2 of 2
## Should you find your home in Biglaw or SmallLaw?
By [Justin Dillon](https://abovethelaw.com/author/justindillon/)  
onFebruary 23, 2017 at 9:57 AMFebruary 23, 2017 at 9:19 AM
0
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/picking-your-system-part-2-of-2/&text=Picking%20Your%20System%20—%20Part%202%20of%202)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/picking-your-system-part-2-of-2/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/picking-your-system-part-2-of-2/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
This is the second installment in my two-part series about the different systems to consider as you think about your career and decide what you want to do with the rest of your life. I’ve been told this advice has been useful to people I’ve discussed it with in the past, so I hope it is helpful to some of you as well. [Last week](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/picking-your-system-part-1-of-2/), I talked about government and in-house work. This week, it’s BigLaw and SmallLaw.

BigLaw

I doubt I have to explain BigLaw to ATL readers. On average, BigLaw will be more lucrative than any of the other systems. If you spend your career in BigLaw, you probably won’t have to worry about whether you can afford to send your kids to private school or pay for college. It also allows you to do a variety of work for different clients, rather than specialize in one area for one client, as you will usually do in government or in-house. And in BigLaw, unlike in a corporation, the lawyer is king.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
To be successful in BigLaw, especially when you’re coming up, you need to let things roll off your back. You can’t, for example, take it personally when you’re a third-year associate and the partner calls you on Friday afternoon and tells you he’s sending you to China for a week — and the plane leaves in three hours. Prickly people tend not to be a great fit for BigLaw.

Your life in BigLaw will also be defined, in many ways, by whether or not you bring in business. And if you’re in BigLaw, that has to be a pretty big number for it to matter to the firm. (Your buddy’s $300,000 contract dispute won’t cut it.)

Origination is freedom — the more you bring in, the more freedom you have.

If you don’t bring in business — regardless of your title — you will, by definition, be doing other people’s work. If you work for the right people, that can be terrific. Finding the right rabbi is one of the single most important things you can do as you plan your career in BigLaw. You could also get lucky, have that rabbi retire, and get handed his clients. Being the relationship partner to a longstanding firm client is the functional equivalent of origination.

###Sponsored

### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
But if you don’t bring in business and never find the right rabbi, life can be hard and stressful. If you work for a rainmaker who is also a jerk, you can find your livelihood completely dependent on someone who treats you like crap and doesn’t care about your life.

You will also have to constantly think about billable pressure, which — as many ATL readers know — can be very stressful. And it gets worse as you get older and have more competing priorities than you do in your youth. Missing a night out with your friends is one thing; missing your kid’s soccer game is another.

Of course, the benefit is — again — that you will make more money. Money will allow you to outsource more things and afford more things. Life is all about tradeoffs.

SmallLaw

And finally, there’s SmallLaw. That’s my favorite system, of course, because it’s where I am. But it may not be the right system for you; I truly am trying to be descriptive and not normative here.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
It’s hard to generalize about SmallLaw. Small firms vary widely in the quality and the amount of their work. Some small firms have lower billable requirements, and some are absolute sweatshops.

Some firms in SmallLaw pay pretty well, and some of them pay less than you’d make in a federal government job.

Public Service Announcement: In SmallLaw, the Cravath scale does not determine associate compensation. Many people who think big thoughts about law firm management suggest that associates should be paid anywhere from 25-33 percent of what is collected from the work they do. If you’re thinking you might like SmallLaw, play around with those numbers, adjusting the number of hours and the billable rate, and see what you get.

If you get the right firm in SmallLaw, it can be a really nice, collaborative place to work. (At the wrong firm, of course, there is nowhere to hide, and it can be hell on earth.) As in BigLaw, you will generally have more flexibility than you will in government or in-house. You don’t have to put in for leave, or get permission to leave early or work from home sometimes. Generally speaking, if you’re doing good work and meeting your hours requirements, you probably won’t be micromanaged.

You’re likely to have more client contact in SmallLaw than you are in BigLaw, because the cases are usually smaller. Think about what you would enjoy more: Would you rather be one of 20 lawyers on a massive case that’s in the news every day, feeling like you’re really doing work that matters on a national or international level? Or would you rather be lawyer number one or two on a case no one will ever know about, but that’s for an individual client you’ve really come to like?

SmallLaw can be riskier than the other systems, but you have to think about what risk means. To some extent, the only real security in the non-government legal world is origination. If you can bring in business, you can always find work somewhere. If you’re in-house, you could get laid off. If you’re a service partner at BigLaw, your rabbi could leave, or your firm could merge and render you redundant.

Plus, to be a successful rainmaker in SmallLaw, the numbers you have to put up are much smaller than they are in BigLaw. You don’t need to bring in Exxon; your buddy’s $300,000 contract case may be just fine. You can also develop a specialty, as I’ve been fortunate enough to do, in an area that’s better suited for SmallLaw than BigLaw.

In my experience at two small firms, SmallLaw can be a hell of a lot of fun. At the right firm, you can have a real sense that you’re building something together — a sense of ownership that can often be hard to find in the law.

***

I have often said that I have my dream job, and I am deeply grateful for that. But I know government lawyers, in-house lawyers, and BigLaw lawyers who say the same thing. There are, as the saying goes, different strokes for different folks. [“What might be right for you, may not be right for some….”](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6jJIVK-daGk)

[Justin Dillon](https://www.kaiserdillon.com/justin-dillon_1.html) is a partner at [KaiserDillon PLLC](https://www.kaiserdillon.com/) in Washington, DC, where he focuses on white-collar criminal defense and campus disciplinary matters. Before joining the firm, he worked as an Assistant United States Attorney in Washington, DC, and at the Civil Rights Division of the Justice Department. His email is [jdillon@kaiserdillon.com](mailto:jdillon@kaiserdillon.com).

# This Biglaw Firm Is Raising Associate Salaries For The Third Time In 2022
## Third time's the charm when it comes to compensation.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMarch 9, 2022 at 1:03 PMMarch 9, 2022 at 12:49 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/cadwalader-match-2022/&text=This%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Is%20Raising%20Associate%20Salaries%20For%20The%20Third%20Time%20In%202022)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/cadwalader-match-2022/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/cadwalader-match-2022/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

What’s better than two raises in less than two months’ time? Three raises!

Cadwalader was the very first firm to [match the Milbank scale](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/cwt-match-22/) back in January. Then the firm quickly [matched the Davis Polk scale](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/cwt-reraises-22/). Now, the firm is matching the Cravath scale.

Here’s what the generous new salary scale looks like at CWT:



Just like the firm’s last two raises, its third will also be retroactive to January 1. Once again, congratulations to everyone at the firm!

(Flip to the next page to see the full memo from Cadwalader.)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of this stuff. So when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we’ll also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# Continuing Tom Girardi Saga Drags Itself Into Yet Another New Year
## A tale slightly older than time ...
By [Jill Switzer](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jillswitzer/)  
onJanuary 4, 2024 at 5:47 PMJanuary 4, 2024 at 3:07 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/continuing-tom-girardi-saga-drags-itself-into-yet-another-new-year/&text=Continuing%20Tom%20Girardi%20Saga%20Drags%20Itself%20Into%20Yet%20Another%20New%20Year)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/continuing-tom-girardi-saga-drags-itself-into-yet-another-new-year/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/continuing-tom-girardi-saga-drags-itself-into-yet-another-new-year/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Thomas Girardi

Phooey on resolutions, but this is the time of year when many of us take stock about where we are, where we’ve been, and where we may want to be in January 2025. Some of us may want to stand pat, but others may be thinking or have been thinking about moving forward, sideways, or even backtracking. It all depends upon what is important to you, a very personal decision. What may be perfect for one person may be horrendous for another. We know, through trial and error (pun intentional), there are many ways to have a career in the law. The perspective of having to have a particular job, to make tons of money, usually changes as we age, and what was worth chasing even a few years ago may no longer be appealing or even doable.

One of the biggest challenges for dinosaur lawyers is when and how to let go. Yes,  clients still need us, or at least we think they do, but what about personal and family needs? When, if ever, do they take priority or even parity with practice? For many dinosaurs, the perplexing question is now what to do and how to do it, to still have purpose and meaning while throttling back. It’s not an easy question to answer. I have friends who are close to 80 (and some beyond that), who are still incredibly sharp, and able to work, but should they? How do they reconnect with a personal and family life left behind years ago when chasing equity partnership and other benefits? Sometimes, you just know when it’s time. Other times, it can take a shove, gentle or otherwise.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Meanwhile, some stories don’t end. My first Tom Girardi story of 2024 (apologies to my editor): a federal judge has determined that [Girardi is competent to stand trial](https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2024-01-02/tom-girardi-declared-incompetent-incompetent-to-stand-trial) for his various alleged misdeeds involving client settlement funds. This ruling is only the beginning of the next chapter.

It’s only January 4, and already I have my first “I am not making this up” for the new year. One law firm is suing another for alleged copyright infringement because Firm A allegedly copied language from Firm B’s brief. What? Is nothing sacred anymore? Nor should it be because, [as Joe Patrice points out](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/boutique-sues-winston-strawn-copyright-brief/), it can verge on malpractice not to copy language. As Joe says, copying is what we do in a common law system. We use the same words and phrases to avoid malpractice, especially in jury instructions where appellate courts have already ruled on  appropriate language to use. Perhaps there might be an issue if the brief was never public record, but in this case, it was and is. I have never seen the © on a brief, at least not so far. Have you?

When I was a junior lawyer, I looked for any help I could get to draft briefs, settlement agreements, and all the other forms of legal documents (this was way before AI). So, the standard answer when I asked for help, which was all the time, was to “go look at the form files.”

Dinosaur lawyers remember form files. They were copies of various and sundry documents/pleadings/agreements/etc. drafted by others and collected in a bunch of file cabinets. File cabinets, another anachronism? The pleadings and the like weren’t always on point, in fact, they rarely were, but they were roadmaps for drafting whatever had to be written, especially for junior lawyers who knew where the restrooms were, but not much more. You still had to research and Shepardize.

From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
No one ever raised a copyright issue; we were all too busy copying from each other. It wasn’t plagiarism, it was using the best mousetrap available for a specific issue. Was it laziness? To the contrary, if you want to talk about laziness, then we can talk about generative AI, but let’s save that for another time.

The form files were usually bulging with past work, from our office and others, even pleadings and briefs from opposing counsel. The test was what would work best in a given situation, and if someone else had a better turn of phrase, a better way to position the argument, to lead the reader in the right direction, then so be it!

If we all had to reinvent the wheel linguistically, the profession would have sunk under the weight of wordiness — and we are wordy enough. There may be ethical issues in copying a brief and charging the client for it, but Joe points out, if copying a brief’s wording saves the client money and gets the necessary points across, what’s wrong with that?

And to end on a California note, heads up for any and all employers who have employees here in the Golden State, who will find that this year is not a happy one. Employees suing for retaliation must show [a nexus between their protected activity and employer retaliation](https://ogletree.com/insights-resources/blog-posts/new-california-law-makes-it-easier-for-employees-to-establish-retaliation-claims/). That’s still the law, but now in California if the employee can show that the adverse employment action occurred within 90 days of the protected activity, the presumption is now that the employer is the bad actor. Remember presumptions from evidence class?

I had always counseled HR that the more attenuated the connection between the protected activity and the adverse employment action, the better. But sometimes it was too tempting not to go “ready, fire, aim.” And they did; itchy trigger fingers bought lawsuits. Now, it’s even easier to sue here in California. [SB 497 has the deets](https://legiscan.com/CA/text/SB497/2023). You’re welcome. You can thank me later, and Happy New Year!

Jill Switzer has been an active member of the State Bar of California for over 40 years. She remembers practicing law in a kinder, gentler time. She’s had a diverse legal career, including stints as a deputy district attorney, a solo practice, and several senior in-house gigs. She now mediates full-time, which gives her the opportunity to see dinosaurs, millennials, and those in-between interact — it’s not always civil. You can reach her by email at [oldladylawyer@gmail.com](mailto:oldladylawyer@gmail.com?subject=Your%20ATL%20column).

# Unvaccinated Lawyers Will Not Be Allowed To Enter This Biglaw Firm
## Getting vaccinated is 'the least that we can do for ourselves, our families and each other as part of our community obligations,' says the firm's managing partner.'
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 30, 2021 at 3:42 PMJune 30, 2021 at 2:51 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/unvaccinated-lawyers-will-not-be-allowed-to-enter-this-biglaw-firm/&text=Unvaccinated%20Lawyers%20Will%20Not%20Be%20Allowed%20To%20Enter%20This%20Biglaw%20Firm)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/unvaccinated-lawyers-will-not-be-allowed-to-enter-this-biglaw-firm/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/unvaccinated-lawyers-will-not-be-allowed-to-enter-this-biglaw-firm/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
[We will] require that all employees, other than those who cannot be vaccinated due to medical or religious reasons, be fully vaccinated before Sept. 13. …

Having all of our employees vaccinated not only helps protect the health and safety of the Mintz community, this requirement also safeguards the health of our clients and others who visit our offices. We will expect clients, vendors and others who enter our offices to provide proof of vaccination (and we will provide for protocols for visitors who cannot provide such proof).

— an excerpt from a memo written by [Bob Bodian](https://www.mintz.com/our-people/robert-i-bodian), managing partner of Mintz, detailing what the [firm’s return to the office](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2021/06/29/mintz-says-no-covid-vaccination-no-office/) will look like. Employees may return voluntarily starting on July 6, and at that time, those who are vaccinated will no longer need to wear masks or socially distance from colleagues. Those who are unvaccinated will [not be allowed in the building](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2021/06/29/mintz-says-no-covid-vaccination-no-office/) and will continue to work remotely until September, because “some employees … have compromised immune systems, and we have an obligation to do our best to protect them, and everyone else, particularly when protection is readily available.”

# First Biglaw Firm To Buy Serious Property In The Metaverse
## Biglaw goes digital.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onFebruary 15, 2022 at 10:44 AMFebruary 16, 2022 at 4:42 PM
13
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/first-biglaw-firm-to-buy-serious-property-in-the-metaverse/&text=First%20Biglaw%20Firm%20To%20Buy%20Serious%20Property%20In%20The%20Metaverse)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/first-biglaw-firm-to-buy-serious-property-in-the-metaverse/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/first-biglaw-firm-to-buy-serious-property-in-the-metaverse/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Listen, full disclosure — I’m not sold on the metaverse yet. The commercials are a weird, uncanny valley and after two years and counting of pandemic-induced isolation, I am ready to be where the people are, not where their avatars are. But, man, the artist formerly known as Facebook is sure pushing the hell out of it.

And a Biglaw firm has bitten. Arent Fox has announced the firm has purchased digital land in the metaverse and is building a virtual office in Decentraland. The firm’s crypto chair, James Williams, [told Law.com](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2022/02/15/arent-fox-buys-property-in-the-metaverse-becoming-first-big-law-firm-with-serious-presence-in-the-virtual-world/) the virtual move is designed to demonstrate to clients that Arent Fox understands the new, digital world:

“The platforms you hear most about are the gaming platforms. But that’s not where the future is. In places like Sandbox and Decentraland you’re buying in locations just like you would buy a Rodeo Drive. You’re trying to get in early,” said Williams, adding that the idea, at a minimum, is to show clients that you’re smart and familiar with the metaverse. “We want to show our clients: We know this world; look, we bought in this world, and we can help them navigate this world.”

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
And even if the future in *not* in the metaverse, the purchase still makes sense for the firm: “[W]e still have a lot of clients moving to this place now, and we want to be where our clients are,” Williams said.

Firm chair Anthony Lupo said the digital investment has already increased its value by 25 percent and that Arent Fox wants to be part of deciding how the metaverse will be used:

“There is a lot of curiosity, but there’s also a lot of confusion about the metaverse, partly because nobody knows what the metaverse is,” said Lupo. “Arent Fox’s move to the metaverse is not only symbolic. We are attempting to find the solution and actually operating in the space. We don’t know what the metaverse will be in five years, but we’re not waiting five years to find out. We’re going to help iterate that future.”

Besides, the metaverse just might help with those work-from-home blues:

“We had our partnership meeting last week, and I announced our purchase of an office in the metaverse,” said Lupo. “I joked that when we return to the office, people that don’t want to come back to the work, we’ll put them in the metaverse office.”

But the jury is still out as to whether this becomes a full-blown Biglaw trend.

# Another West Coast Firm Adopts The $180K Salary Structure
## Chalk up another big raise!
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 7, 2016 at 6:00 PMJune 7, 2016 at 6:02 PM
1
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/another-west-coast-firm-adopts-the-180k-salary-structure/&text=Another%20West%20Coast%20Firm%20Adopts%20The%20$180K%20Salary%20Structure)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/another-west-coast-firm-adopts-the-180k-salary-structure/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/another-west-coast-firm-adopts-the-180k-salary-structure/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Last night, California-based litigation boutique Hueston Hennigan became [the first firm to officially match](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/another-firm-bumps-associate-salaries-to-match-180k-scale/) Cravath’s new $180K salary structure. Today, there’s more good news out West as the firm Hueston Hennigan largely grew out of, Irell & Manella, joins the new normal.

We routinely bank on Irell to [beat the market in associate compensation](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/12/associate-bonus-watch-same-as-it-ever-was/), so we had few doubts they’d be an early adopter of the new pay structure. When the firm bested market bonuses last year, some of our tipsters were still annoyed that the firm didn’t offer even more. So far we’ve not heard the same complaints about this bump.

Congrats folks!

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)

Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

# The Largest Law Firms With The Most Women Lawyers (2020)
## An important ranking to show which firms are helping women achieve successful careers in the law.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 24, 2020 at 3:42 PMJune 24, 2020 at 2:42 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/the-largest-law-firms-with-the-most-women-lawyers-2020/&text=The%20Largest%20Law%20Firms%20With%20The%20Most%20Women%20Lawyers%20(2020))[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/the-largest-law-firms-with-the-most-women-lawyers-2020/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/the-largest-law-firms-with-the-most-women-lawyers-2020/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Photo via Getty)

Earlier this week, thanks to the recently released National Law Journal 500 ranking, we found out which U.S.-centric Biglaw firms were the [biggest of them all in terms of headcount](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/the-500-largest-law-firms-in-america-2020/). As a companion piece to the NLJ 500, today we’ve got the NLJ Women’s Scorecard, a ranking of the percentage of female attorneys and percentage of female partners at the largest 350 firms in the country.

For this ranking, both equity and nonequity partners were counted as partners, while nonpartner or “other” figures include special counsel, of counsel, and other staff attorneys. Temporary and contract attorneys aren’t included in the count. In the event of a tie, the higher rank is awarded to the firm with more female equity partners.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
In all, 265 of the country’s 350 largest firms by head count reported data for the scorecard. Among the respondents, women accounted for 37.2% of the firms’ 143,454 lawyers in 2019, and 47.7% of 68,250 associates. …

Female representation at the partner level once again lagged in 2019: across the board, women comprised only 24.2% of all partnerships, out of 59,176 total partners, and only 20.5% of the equity partnership ranks.

Without further ado, here is the NLJ Women’s Scorecard Top 10 for 2020:

- Berry Appleman & Leiden
- Fragomen
- Hanson Bridgett
- Littler Mendelson
- Constangy Brooks Smith & Prophete
- FordHarrison
- Wood Smith Henning & Berman
- Manning Gross + Massenburg
- Ogletree Deakins
- Jackson Lewis
You may be wondering where the largest, namebrand Biglaw firms appear on this list. While the majority of the top 30 firms on the scorecard have a headcount of about 300 or less, there were some exceptions, with Fragomen, Littler, Ogletree, Jackson Lewis, Ropes & Gray, Wilson Elser, Shook Hardy, Gordon Rees, Lewis Brisbois, Baker McKenzie, and Quarles & Brady all making an appearance in the top 30. Firms like Ropes & Gray and Ogletree both made major strides, with Ropes cracking the Top 20 for the first time ever (the firm’s chair is a woman and four of its 10 board members are women) and Ogletree joining the Top 10 (the firm recently created a sponsorship program to support female nonequity partners advancing to the equity level).

# NY To $190K: An Addendum On Leverage
## In figuring out which Biglaw firm will bring us the next pay raise, it's important to consider the concept of leverage.
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onMay 23, 2016 at 6:17 PMMay 25, 2016 at 4:05 PM
14
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/05/ny-to-190k-an-addendum-on-leverage/&text=NY%20To%20$190K:%20An%20Addendum%20On%20Leverage)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/05/ny-to-190k-an-addendum-on-leverage/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/05/ny-to-190k-an-addendum-on-leverage/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Last week, I offered some thoughts on which Biglaw firm might [lead the next round of pay raises](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/05/ny-to-190k-who-will-lead-the-charge/). I nominated Cravath, which in many ways is still the leader of the pack when it comes to New York’s elite, old-guard, white-shoe firms. (I didn’t focus on places like Wachtell Lipton and Quinn Emanuel, which are a bit different — younger and more narrowly focused in their practices compared to places like Cravath, Sullivan & Cromwell, Davis Polk, and Simpson Thacher).

A reader raised this important point in response to my article:

Have you considered writing about the role of leverage in the jump to $190K? On a profits-per-partner basis, Skadden (with a leverage of 3.5) would have an easier time raising salaries than Davis Polk (4.9), to the tune of about $45,000 per partner (assuming $30k raises across the board). In a world where firms game many of their accounting measures to boost PPP [profits per partner], I’m sure a margin of that size enters the calculus.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
As noted in the American Lawyer’s latest [ranking of firms by profitability](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202755651549/Firms-Ranked-by-Profitability-#ixzz49DWgd4r2), part of the recently released [Am Law 100](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/04/the-2016-am-law-100-trouble-ahead/) rankings, leverage “is the ratio of all lawyers (minus equity partners) to equity partners.” The higher a firm’s leverage, the more an associate pay raise will cut into partner profits. For example, if a firm has leverage of 5 to 1 — i.e., five lawyers (excluding equity partners) for every one equity partner — giving every lawyer a $20,000 pay raise should increase overhead and reduce profits per equity partner by $100,000 (5 x $20,000). (Note: that example admittedly oversimplifies things a bit, but you get the point.)

As suggested by the reader comment posted above, it seems reasonable to assume that all else being equal, a firm with low leverage would be more willing and able to raise associate salaries than a firm with high leverage. It also seems reasonable to assume, based on the [history of Biglaw pay raises](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/05/ny-to-190k-who-will-lead-the-charge/), that the salary hike will come from a super-prestigious firm.

Every year, our friends at Vault rank the nation’s [100 most prestigious law firms](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/06/2016-vault-law-firm-rankings-self-perpetuating-prestige/). If you take the [top 15 Vault firms](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/06/2016-vault-law-firm-rankings-self-perpetuating-prestige/) and rank them by [leverage according to Am Law](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202755651549/Firms-Ranked-by-Profitability-#ixzz49DWgd4r2), here’s what the list looks like (from lowest to highest leverage, and with Vault rank in parentheses after each firm’s name):

1. Covington & Burling (V13) – 2.09
2. Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz (V1) – 2.11
3. Gibson Dunn & Crutcher (V11) – 3.08
4. Quinn Emanuel Urquhart & Sullivan (V15) – 3.32
5. Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom (V3) – 3.47
6. Kirkland & Ellis (V7) – 3.61
7. Sullivan & Cromwell (V4) – 3.71
8. Latham & Watkins (V10) – 3.80
9. Simpson Thacher & Bartlett (V6) – 4.14
10. Cravath, Swaine & Moore (V2) – 4.24
11. Davis Polk & Wardwell (V5) – 4.86
12. Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton (V8) – 5.36
13. Boies, Schiller & Flexner (V12) – 5.38
14. Weil, Gotshal & Manges (V9) – 5.48
15. Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison (V14) – 5.80
